Mortgage.definition: a conveyance of title to property that is given to secure an obligation
Mortgage.origin: [Anglo-French, from Old French, from mort dead (from Latin mortuus ) + gage security]

1 a.definition: a conveyance of title to property that is given to secure an obligation (as a debt) and that is defeated upon payment or performance according to stipulated terms [shows that a deed was intended only as a "W. M. McGovern, Jr."]

sub_terms.b: a lien against property that is granted to secure an obligation (as a debt) and that is extinguished upon payment or performance according to stipulated terms [creditors with validagainst the debtor's property "J. H. Williamson"]
sub_terms.c: a loan secured by a mortgage [applied for a ]

1 a.s: against the debtor's property "J. H. Williamson"]

adjustable rate mortgage.definition: a mortgage having an interest rate which is usually initially lower than that of a mortgage with a fixed rate but which is adjusted periodically according to an index (as the cost of funds to the lender)

balloon mortgage.definition: a mortgage having the interest paid periodically and the principal paid in one lump sum at the end of the term of the loan

blanket mortgage.definition: a mortgage of or against all of the property of the mortgagor

chattel mortgage.definition: a mortgage of or against personal or movable property (as an airplane) compareat

collateral mortgage.definition: a mortgage against movable or immovable property that is given to secure a written obligation (as a note) which is pledged as collateral security for a principal obligation see alsoat

construction mortgage.definition: a mortgage that secures a loan which finances construction

1.definition: to grant or convey by a mortgage [the property to the bank]

equitable mortgage.definition: a constructive or implied mortgagea transaction (as a conveyance) that does not have the form of a mortgage but is given the effect of a mortgage by a court of equity because the parties intended it to be a mortgage

first mortgage.definition: a mortgage that has priority over all other security interests except those imposed by law

fixed rate mortgage.definition: a mortgage having an interest rate that stays the same

general mortgage.definition: a blanket mortgage that burdens all present and future property

judicial mortgage.definition: a mortgage lien that secures a judgment debt and is created by filing a judgment with the recorder of mortgages

leasehold mortgage.definition: a mortgage under which a leasehold interest in property secures a loan or obligation

legal mortgage.definition: a mortgage that secures an obligation which is created by a law and which does not have to be stipulated to by the parties

open-end mortgage.definition: a mortgage that secures a loan agreement which allows the mortgagor to borrow additional sums usually up to a specified limit

purchase money mortgage.definition: a mortgage that is given (as to a lender) to secure a loan for all or some of the purchase price of propertya mortgage given to a seller of property to secure the unpaid balance of the purchase price

reverse mortgage.definition: a mortgage that allows elderly homeowners to convert existing equity into available funds provided through a line of credit, a cash advance (as for the purchase of an annuity), or periodic disbursements to be repaid with interest when the home is sold or ceases to be the primary residence, when the borrower dies or some other specified event occurs, or at a fixed maturity date

second mortgage.definition: a mortgage lien that is subordinate in priority to a first mortgage called also

wrap-around mortgage.definition: [rap-É™-rand-]a second or later mortgage that incorporates the debt of a previous mortgage with additional debt for another loan

2 a.definition: an instrument embodying and containing the provisions of a mortgage [executing and recording]
